justification: The authors state that they "quantified these types of predicted differences by calculating … the entropy of the frequency distribution over orange, blue, and purple tiles in a trajectory (color visitation entropy)", using it to capture targeted variability.
In Experiment 2 they note that "we focused on jumping rate and risky jumping rate, as these are key signatures of belief-directed planning," treating risky-jump frequency as the indicator.
During Experiment 1b observers "answered … their confidence on a continuous scale (0 to 100)", making the slider rating the operational measure of confidence.
Observer performance was analysed with "correct/incorrect judgments as the outcome variable," so accuracy was gauged by whether each color judgment was right or wrong.
Király et al. (2013) assessed imitation by whether children "attempted to turn the light on with their head", i.e., the frequency of head-use actions.

measured_by: infant looking times to incongruent trials
justification: Hernik & Csibra (2015) report "significantly greater looking times on incongruent test trials, indicating that infants' expectations were violated," using looking duration as the metric.
